newsitem.title: USA: Fed stands by U.S. TIPS as a policy tool - S.F. Fed.
newsitem.headline: Fed stands by U.S. TIPS as a policy tool - S.F. Fed.

text.p: Wall Street has not been enthusiastic about the Treasury's inflation-linked securities, but the Federal Reserve sees the issues as a gauge of future inflation expectations and a valuable monetary policy tool.
"An important role the bond markets... play (in monetary policy) is to sort of provide information," Glenn Rudebusch, a research officer at the San Francisco Fed, told Reuters.

He said the Treasury's new Inflation Protected Securities, better known as TIPS, provide a more evident distinction between nominal and real interest rates, which in turn helps the Fed "understand or gauge expectations of inflation."
"Some of the new financial instruments have helped to provide more information on the economy to the Fed.
"Information about expectations is important, and using the real and nominal debt to get a better handle on those expectations is also important," Rudebusch said.

The Treasury's first TIPS auction took place on January 29 with the sale of $7.0 billion in 10-year inflation-linked securities. The government re-opened the issue in April with the placement of $8.0 billion.
On July 9, the Treasury sold $8.0 billion in its first five-year TIPS sale. The government now has plans to launch a 30-year issue next year.
In an environment of falling inflation, the TIPS haven't been very popular among investors, and most auctions have been met with lukewarm reception from Wall Street.
The return on the TIPS is calculated by combining the seasonally unadjusted Consumer Price Index (CPI) plus a money market premium.
Rudebusch said another aspect of interest rates that has become particularly important for the operation of the Fed's monetary policy is the term structure relationship of short- and long-term rates.
"Long-term interest rates are formed on the expectation of future short-term interest rates," he said.
"So to the extent that you can discern those expectations ... that helps you understand where markets view the future path of monetary policy and the economy," the San Fransciso Fed economist added.
Interest rates have been playing a larger role in monetary policy as informational indicators, mainly after the notion of tying policy and money aggregates weakened a decade ago.
"In the postwar period, the ultimate objectives of the Federal Reserve -- namely full employment and stable prices -- have remained unchanged.
"However, the Fed has modified its operational and intermediate objectives for monetary policy several times in response to changes in the economic environment," the San Francisco Fed economist said.
